Ladies and Gentlemen...

Setting the environment CLASSPATH to run simple Ja=
va applications is just another way to use global data. The environment CLA=
SSPATH is global data and should be avoided.

May I recommend specifying th=
e CLASSPATH you need each time you run a Java application without stuffing =
extra crap into your environment. This way you know exactly what's on the C=
LASSPATH each time you run the application.

Take care.

>So said Jason Rog=
ers on 2003-07-04 --------------------
>On Fri, 04 Jul 2003 19:30:28 -0000,=
 "sutantoc74" <sutantoc74@...>
>said:
>> Hi All,
>> 
>> I am new with=
 JUnit. I have two test files and one test suite file, 
>> unfortunately wh=
en I try to run the testrunner from any directory, I 
>> always get a NoCla=
ssDefFoundError.
>> [snip]
>> Can somebody let me know what's wrong? Thanks=

>
>Charles,
>
>This is a typical Java classpath issue.  What class name is=
 in the stack
>trace?  Make sure that class in on your classpath.  From a c=
ommandline
>you can type one of the following to see what your classpath is=
 set to...
>
>    Unix:    echo $CLASSPATH
>    Windows: echo %CLASSPATH%
>=

>--
>=3Djason
